awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  College Bound Video Game
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impacts of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will result from the production of a useful game, called College Bound, that will entice youth to use their gaming time to learn how to navigate the college preparation, college-admissions, and financial-aid processes.  This assistance could help in addressing the problem of an inadequate number of counselors in high schools that serve large minority populations. Studies have shown that underserved high school students see a counselor for less than 20 minutes a year.  Since is also known that young people between the ages of 8-18 spend 7.5 hours a day engaged with media- either playing video games or watching television a game platform may enable minority students, who make up less than 4% of undergraduate enrollees in the national four-year colleges, to prepare for college attendence. The College Bound game seeks to recoup some of this screen time for positive benefits such as improving preparedness of the minority students to access higher education, and meeting future workforce demands in Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics, and Medicine (STEMM).

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project focuses on assisting underrepresented students in learning about what it takes to get college admission, how to prepare for it, and what financial aid is available to afford the education using a gaming environment. The project will focus on measuring students' knowledge about the college application process as the player navigates through different levels of the game. Knowledge about the college application process includes a) information about admission criteria and deadlines, b) the college acceptance and enrollment processes, and c) the ability to pay for college through scholarships, loans, work programs, and/or personal savings. Throughout the pilot phase, the project will develop reliable and valid evaluation tools to measure student learning in the game setting at each level of the College Bound game. These evaluation tools might reflect not only student learning performance but also boost college enrollment outcomes. These measures may also enable the school and other stakeholders to understand students' gaps and help strengthen students’ pathways into college.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Laying the Groundwork for an Innovative College Prep Game

 Customer Discovery and Insights

Our project's Phase I efforts focused extensively on laying the groundwork for an educational video game called ADMITnGO aimed at assisting high school students through the intricacies of the college preparation process.

 A major portion of Phase I involved deep customer discovery through 31 intensive interviews with school counselors to thoroughly understand the obstacles they face guiding students through college applications, particularly those in under-resourced urban schools. These conversations offered extremely valuable insights emphasizing counselors’ vital role in college access. The perspectives gained illuminated assumptions about constraints counselors contend with in advising students. Furthermore, participation in the NSF I-Corps program has facilitated 100 more comprehensive customer discovery interviews to expand our knowledge foundation and prepare for Phase II by developing an even richer understanding of user needs.

 Game Development and Testing

Game design and iterative development was another key focus area, closely tied to testing and evaluation. Early qualitative testing revealed our initial gameplay roadmap required adapting to match the experience emerging through user input. Consequently, we pivoted our evaluation criteria and success metrics to fit the evolving vision. Phase I evaluations focused on baseline assessments of usability, navigation and flow via questionnaires. Building on these learnings, Phase II will expand evaluation and refinement.

 While designing the game concept, we maintained a highly customer-centric approach given counselors’ integral role guiding students. Our journey to gain insights proved invaluable in highlighting counselors’ importance in college access. These perspectives will continue shaping the product going forward.

 Overall, Phase I established a strong foundation through extensive customer discovery, adaptable development and testing, and foundational usability evaluations. These efforts enabled key learnings to propel future work.

 Technical Game Development

On the technical side, we developed a functional prototype on the Unity platform. Key elements included 2D graphic assets and core mechanics enabling progression through increasingly challenging gameplay levels. As users acquire knowledge about the college process, they can unlock new levels and deepen their expertise. Additional features allowed attending virtual college fairs, building profiles, and safely connecting with other players for motivation.

 To assess and refine the game, we conducted a qualitative user study with 40 middle school students using pre- and post-gameplay questionnaires. Results demonstrated increased understanding and self-efficacy after interacting with the game. Participants also provided feedback on enjoyability factors like aesthetics, navigation ease, and intuitive design. We embraced this user input to refine components like tutorials to enhance accessibility for our target 13-19 demographic. This commitment to an iterative design process allowed continuously improving engagement and learning impact.

Business Development and Operation

On the operational side, we focused on foundational business development spanning branding, web presence, grant applications, and school district partnerships. Strategic planning centered on crafting a detailed commercialization roadmap outlining targeted milestones.

 Understanding customers and charting a successful course required nuanced strategies. We realized moving beyond demographics to grasp core user needs was crucial. Consequently, we are shifting focus to deeper partnerships that provide greater relevance to our audience, like working closely with schools, teachers and education companies.

 The discovery process also reshaped our perspective. Interviews yielded insights challenging assumptions about counselor obstacles and student needs. This informed a more tailored approach to guide users through personalized game experiences. The journey underscored letting robust discovery refine initial hypotheses to enable more meaningful product development.

 Key operational enhancements involved pursuing strategic partnerships and broadening distribution channels. Assessing potential revenue stream diversification is also a priority, informed by customer insights and market data. This emphasis on strategic evolution ensures we stay attuned to user needs at the forefront of educational gaming.

 Conclusion and Future Direction

Overall, Phase I accomplished the vital groundwork needed to fulfill our vision. Conducting extensive customer research while translating those insights into initial game design and assets enabled progress. This balanced approach combining real user perspectives with interactive learning has unlocked an engaging tool to expand college access.

 Moving forward into Phase II, priorities involve finalizing adaptive gameplay tailored to individual needs, securing informed consent, and expanding research reach. Partnerships with education nonprofits and platforms can amplify our distribution capabilities. Our team remains dedicated to refining an accessible, enjoyable game that provides personalized guidance empowering the college journeys of students nationwide. We are eager to build on the insights and accomplishments of Phase I to bring this innovative solution to life.

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2023
Modified by: Laura Hayes

por.por_txt_cntn:
Laying the Groundwork for an Innovative College Prep Game



Customer Discovery and Insights


Our project's Phase I efforts focused extensively on laying the groundwork for an educational video game called ADMITnGO aimed at assisting high school students through the intricacies of the college preparation process.


A major portion of Phase I involved deep customer discovery through 31 intensive interviews with school counselors to thoroughly understand the obstacles they face guiding students through college applications, particularly those in under-resourced urban schools. These conversations offered extremely valuable insights emphasizing counselors vital role in college access. The perspectives gained illuminated assumptions about constraints counselors contend with in advising students. Furthermore, participation in the NSF I-Corps program has facilitated 100 more comprehensive customer discovery interviews to expand our knowledge foundation and prepare for Phase II by developing an even richer understanding of user needs.

Game design and iterative development was another key focus area, closely tied to testing and evaluation. Consequently, we pivoted our evaluation criteria and success metrics to fit the evolving vision. Phase I evaluations focused on baseline assessments of usability, navigation and flow via questionnaires. Building on these learnings, Phase II will expand evaluation and refinement.


While designing the game concept, we maintained a highly customer-centric approach given counselors integral role guiding students. Our journey to gain insights proved invaluable in highlighting counselors importance in college access. These perspectives will continue shaping the product going forward.


Overall, Phase I established a strong foundation through extensive customer discovery, adaptable development and testing, and foundational usability evaluations. These efforts enabled key learnings to propel future work.

On the technical side, we developed a functional prototype on the Unity platform. Key elements included 2D graphic assets and core mechanics enabling progression through increasingly challenging gameplay levels. Assessing potential revenue stream diversification is also a priority, informed by customer insights and market data. Moving forward into Phase II, priorities involve finalizing adaptive gameplay tailored to individual needs, securing informed consent, and expanding research reach.
